Award.AwardTitle: Analyzing Neuronal Activity When Classical Reaction-Diffusion Breaks Down
Award.AbstractNarration: Intuitively it is reasonable to agree that even when all the reactants are the same the biochemical reactions that take place in a laboratory test tube should probably differ from those that take place in highly complex neurons. The purpose of this project is to develop a theoretical framework to understand the fundamental structural properties of neurons that can completely modify the outcome of the biochemical reactions that are at the foundation of learning and memory. This project will make use of computer simulations that to study how the structure of the surface and interior of neurons affects molecular reactions involved in memory formation. A branch of mathematics, called fractional calculus, will be used to generalize the findings of the simulations. The same formalism will be extended to study how neurons express proteins or how networks of neurons interact with each other. The project will generate knowledge to study the outcome of experiments aimed at understanding memory formation, complex proteins networks, and information processing in the cerebellum; this work will also provide a unified mathematical framework to understand the exquisite interaction between biochemical signals and the complex structure of neurons in which they take place. The knowledge generated will be disseminated with a computational toolbox that can be used in any area of biology interested in complex systems, from biochemistry to ecology. This proposal will provide training opportunities to minority bilingual undergraduates not only in the scientific aspects of the project but also to develop Wikipedia pages in Spanish to help the American Hispanic population get better access to scientific information in neuroscience and biophysics. The project will also allow the training of a graduate student and post-doctoral fellows which will enrich the academic environment of UTSA, a Hispanic serving institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to develop a computational and theoretical framework to study neuronal activity, from molecules to the entire cell, when the assumptions used in the classical physical theories break down. While classical theories, such as mass transport and classical reaction-diffusion, have contributed greatly to predict certain aspects of brain function there is increasing evidence that, in multiple cases, the assumptions of these theories are not applicable to the complex morphological, metabolical, and electrophysiological properties of neurons. Since most of the processes in neurons are modeled with a single theory, reaction-diffusion, we decided to concentrate on such phenomena at multiple levels of biological organization in neurons.

The basic hypothesis of our work is constructed as  follows: In a test tube a biochemical reaction is limited only by the speed of the reaction because all the components are well mixed. The complex interaction of macro-proteins, structures, organelles, and neuronal morphology generates a micro-environment in the neuron in which the reactions cannot be described as in being in a test tube. In such cases, the complexity of the neuronal structure affects the neuronal behavior in ways that cannot be predicted with the classical theories. In such cases the system is known to be outside equilibrium.

First, we identified that in order to describe a process outside equilibrium we needed to use a different type of equation. It turns out that, as the natural mathematical tool to describe the classical reaction-diffusion process is the differential reaction-diffusion equation, when a system is outisde equilibrium the natural tools is to use a fractional order equation. Fractional order differential equations have been known for about 300 years, however, they have been used only in the last 30 years because of the availability of computer power and also be cause of a better understanding of the physical sources of the pheonmenon. In essence,  a fractional differential describes how far a proces is from classical equilibrium.

Second,  we recongnized that solving efficiently and effectively fractional integro-differeintial equation was a limiting factor to advance the use of this tool. For this reason we developed a toolbox with algorithms that could integrate these equations. In fact, a recent review of toolbox in the field has shown that our algorithms are the fastest and most accurate.

Third, we applied our toolbox to multiple problems to study intracellular biochemical signalling in neurons. However, a significang intellectual leap was to use these tools to study the membrane voltage dynamics. Since the equations used to describe the flow of ions accross a membrance are mathematically identical to the reaction-diffusion equation we reasoned that we could use our framework. We proposed that the interactions of membrane conductances results in a complex behavior of the conductance that can be desribed with fractional dynamics. We have demonstrated that using this principle we can reproduce non-classical neuronal action potential time adaptation in mutliple neuronal types.

Finally, we have started to develop models of neural networks to understand how such small system can transmit high information rates. This grant provided us the basis of our recently awared BREAIN-EAGER project. There we develop new ideas to apply the same framework to study complex animal, bird song generation, and human behavior, EEG while reading.
